text:
Interesting critique to the most idealist/abstract side of ourselves :slightly_smiling_face:

<https://twitter.com/danluu/status/1475769364456501250>

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/danluu|@danluu>: In general, I don't think it's very interesting when someone spends a lot of time talking about how much better the world would be if we all listened to them when they don't discuss specific details about what mechanisms would make things better and why. <https://twitter.com/hillelogram/status/1474111409365655559>
attachments.text: In general, I don't think it's very interesting when someone spends a lot of time talking about how much better the world would be if we all listened to them when they don't discuss specific details about what mechanisms would make things better and why. <https://twitter.com/hillelogram/status/1474111409365655559>

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/hillelogram|@hillelogram>: Vision and speculation are great, but Kay often criticizes modern computing for not matching his vision. But maybe it's his vision that was off? Maybe kids would never have used a Dynabook the way he imagined they'd use it

elements.text: Interesting critique to the most idealist/abstract side of ourselves

text: this blog post has been my go-to on cutting edge access controls. The biscuits at the end blows my mind. <https://fly.io/blog/api-tokens-a-tedious-survey/#macaroons|https://fly.io/blog/api-tokens-a-tedious-survey/#macaroons>

elements.text: this blog post has been my go-to on cutting edge access controls. The biscuits at the end blows my mind.

text: Kay once attributed the slowdown in computers to a Butler Lampson quote, something like operating systems have gotten 5000x slower, largely negating hardware gains. But I could never find the source for it. That claim does seem plausible to me; my laptop (seems to) take as long to boot now as my desktop did 20 years ago. Maybe I'll buy Dan's patreon to get the details.

elements.text: Kay once attributed the slowdown in computers to a Butler Lampson quote, something like operating systems have gotten 5000x slower, largely negating hardware gains. But I could never find the source for it. That claim does seem plausible to me; my laptop (seems to) take as long to boot now as my desktop did 20 years ago. Maybe I'll buy Dan's patreon to get the details.

text: It’s entirely possible that Kay’s vision was off

elements.text: It’s entirely possible that Kay’s vision was off

text: The problem is that we don’t have the conceptual framework for evaluating whether or not this is the case

elements.text: The problem is that we don’t have the conceptual framework for evaluating whether or not this is the case

text: His vision is so tied to the concept of conventional literacy and its effects that you’d have to be able to say something concrete about what conventional literacy actually is (and therefore what “literacy-like” technologies are, if anything)

elements.text: His vision is so tied to the concept of conventional literacy and its effects that you’d have to be able to say something concrete about what conventional literacy actually is (and therefore what “literacy-like” technologies are, if anything)

text: It turns out that’s really difficult. Empirically, Scriber and Cole were the only ones to take a shot at it and it was a mixed bag. There hasn’t been much work on the psychology part of it since the 70s as far as I know

elements.text: It turns out that’s really difficult. Empirically, Scriber and Cole were the only ones to take a shot at it and it was a mixed bag. There hasn’t been much work on the psychology part of it since the 70s as far as I know

text: What does it mean for a vision to be "off"?

elements.text: What does it mean for a vision to be "off"?
